newsitem.title: INDIA: India I-Sec predicts rally in zero coupon bonds.
newsitem.headline: India I-Sec predicts rally in zero coupon bonds.

text.p: India's ICICI Securities & Finance Company (I-Sec) said it expected prices of zero percent 1999 and zero percent 2000 (III) securities to climb in the next few weeks.
"The zero percent 1999 trading at an yield of 12.52 percent gives a 257 basis point differential over the 16 January treasury bill," I-Sec said in a debt market commentary.
I-Sec is the Indian affiliate of investment bank J.P.Morgan.

"This differential is even more glaring at 371 basis points when yield on zero percent 1999 is computed on a money market basis (13.66 percent) to make it comparable with treasury bill yields," it said.
It said such a large maturity spread was not warranted by the one-year difference between the two securities.

"We should see the price of the zero percent 1999 move up by a rupee or more over the next fortnight. Hence switching from the 16 January treasury bill to zero percent 1999 is likely to offer excellent holding period returns," it said.
Another buy opportunity at current price levels, but not as good as zero percent 1999, was zero percent 2000, I-Sec said.
This security traded at an yield of 13.35 percent, was marginally higher than the yield on 13.55 percent 2001 despite having a lower residual maturity as well as lower duration.

"Additionally, the duration on the zero percent 2000 (III) will decrease at a faster pace than duration on the 13.55 percent 2001. This is a good opportunity for investors to switch from 13.55 percent 2001 to zero percent 2000 (III), thus improving the yield and reducing the risk (duration)," it said.
